cultural_note: The most important phrase in the souk.

french: Je parle un peu de Darija

arabic: واش كاين شي حد كيهضر نگليزية؟
pronunciation: wash KAYN shi HAD kay-HDER ng-li-ZI-ya

french: S'il te plaît, donne-moi le menu

cultural_note: Asking if something is locally made vs imported.
Good luck with this one — most petit taxis in tourist areas 'forget' the meter.
The most popular coffee order in Morocco — half coffee, half steamed milk.
The best compliment for a Moroccan cook.
Said before, during, or after a meal. Also after someone showers or gets a haircut.

french: Je peux prendre le petit-déjeuner ici ?

cultural_note: Say this when you see something beautiful to ward off the evil eye.

french: Que Dieu te donne la santé
cultural_note: Said to thank anyone who did work — the waiter, the cook, the taxi driver.
Said when mentioning the deceased.

english: May God make it easy for you

darija: Lli bgha l3sel ysbr 3la qrss nnhal
arabic: اللي بغى العسل يصبر على قرص النحل
english: He who wants honey must endure bee stings
french: Qui veut le miel doit supporter les piqûres
pronunciation: lli BGHA l-3SEL ys-BER 3la QRSS n-NHAL
literal_translation: Who wanted honey must be patient with bee stings

cultural_note: Moroccan way of saying let go of the past.

french: On ne peut pas fuir son destin
cultural_note: Core Moroccan belief in destiny (mektub).
literal_translation: From what's written there's no escape
Who has money buys the air

french: Une main seule ne peut pas applaudir

english: I need to go to the hospital
Excuse me, do you speak English?

cultural_note: Moroccans are incredibly helpful with lost tourists. Someone will walk you there.

english: Please show me on the map

cultural_note: Very important at restaurants. Follow with: l-fwl sodani (peanuts), l-7lib (dairy), l-gluten

darija: Wash hna f ttri9 l jami3 lfna?
arabic: واش حنا ف الطريق لجامع الفنا؟
english: Are we on the way to Jemaa el-Fna?
french: On est bien vers Jemaa el-Fna ?
pronunciation: wash 7NA f t-TRIQ l ja-MI3 l-FNA

french: Je n'ai pas compris, répétez svp

english: I need to go to the hospital

cultural_note: Moroccans love hearing this. They'll slow down and help you practice.

darija: Shhal hadi w nta f lmghrib?
arabic: شحال هادي و نتا ف المغرب؟
english: How long have you been in Morocco?
french: Depuis combien de temps au Maroc ?
pronunciation: sh-HAL HA-di w n-TA f l-MGHRIB

darija: Wash kayn shi blasa hna l wifi?
arabic: واش كاين شي بلاصة هنا للويفي؟
french: Il y a du wifi ici ?
pronunciation: wash KAYN shi BLA-sa HNA l WI-fi

cultural_note: This signals you're serious. The seller will usually give their real bottom price.

english: Too expensive, lower it a bit
literal_translation: Expensive too much, reduce for me a little

cultural_note: Essential for navigating souks without being pulled into every shop.

english: I'll bring my friends to buy
cultural_note: Works as a gentle bargaining tactic — implies future business.

darija: 3tini wahd mn hada w wahd mn hadak
arabic: عطيني واحد من هادا و واحد من هاداك
english: Give me one of this and one of that
french: Donnez-moi un de ça et un de ça
pronunciation: 3ti-NI WAH-d mn HA-da w WAH-d mn ha-DAK

cultural_note: Petit taxis should use meters. If they refuse, negotiate price before getting in.

english: Can you take me and bring me back?
cultural_note: Useful for day trips. Negotiate total price upfront including wait time.

french: Un thé à la menthe, svp

cultural_note: Noss-noss is Morocco's signature coffee drink — half espresso, half steamed milk.

english: Do you have anything to eat?
french: Il y a quelque chose à manger ?

english: Can I sit on the terrace?

cultural_note: Nearly all food in Morocco is halal, but good to confirm at international restaurants.

french: Il y a du couscous aujourd'hui ?
cultural_note: Couscous is traditionally served on Fridays. Many restaurants only make it that day.

darija: Wash l fttur dakhil f ttaman?
pronunciation: wash l ft-TUR DA-khil f t-TA-man

english: Can I eat on the terrace?
french: Je peux manger sur la terrasse ?
cultural_note: Most riads serve breakfast on the rooftop. Always ask — it's the best way to start the day.

french: Il y a un transfert aéroport ?

darija: Wash kayn bit b vue 3la l jnina?
arabic: واش كاين بيت بڤو على الجنينة؟
pronunciation: wash KAYN BIT b VU 3la l jni-NA

english: I'll recommend you to my friends
french: Je vous recommanderai à mes amis

english: God give you health (thanks for work)
french: Que Dieu te donne la santé
cultural_note: Said to anyone doing physical work — shopkeepers, waiters, workers. Very appreciated.
Used to express admiration — at someone's house, seeing their children, complimenting work.
Said after someone eats, drinks, buys new clothes, gets a haircut, or takes a shower.
One of the deepest compliments in Darija. Shows genuine gratitude.
literal_translation: God have mercy on your parents

cultural_note: Said before exams, interviews, difficult tasks, or travel. Universal encouragement.

english: In the name of God (before eating/starting)
cultural_note: Said before eating, drinking, starting any task, entering a home. Universal.
The most common expression in Morocco. Used after meals, when asked how you are, after good news.
Added to ANY statement about the future. 'See you tomorrow' → 'Ntshafu ghdda inshallah'
Said when admiring something — a baby, a house, someone's success. Wards off evil eye.
Always said when someone mentions a deceased person. Very important etiquette.

french: Que Dieu te donne le succès

cultural_note: Even basic Darija earns this compliment. Moroccans genuinely appreciate the effort.

french: Vous avez un très beau pays

english: Your people are dear to my heart
french: Vos gens me sont chers au cœur

cultural_note: Always say tbarkllah/mashallah when complimenting children — protects from evil eye.

french: Je suis diabétique, j'ai besoin de sucre
On m'a volé ! Appelez la police !
Où est la pharmacie la plus proche ?

english: Patience is the key to relief
french: La patience est la clé du soulagement
literal_translation: Patience is the key to relief

darija: Lli bgha l3ssl ysbr l qrss dyal nn7l
arabic: اللي بغا العسل يصبر لقرص ديال النحل
english: Who wants honey must bear the bee stings
french: Qui veut le miel supporte les piqûres
pronunciation: lli bgha l-3SSL ys-BR l-QRSS dyal n-N7L
cultural_note: Nothing worth having comes easy.
literal_translation: Who wants honey must endure bee stings

english: Do good and forget about it
cultural_note: Core Moroccan value — give without expecting return.

french: Une seule main ne peut applaudir

english: Stretch your legs to match your blanket
cultural_note: Live within your means.
literal_translation: According to the blanket, stretch your legs

cultural_note: Today's king may be tomorrow's pauper. Stay humble.

english: Knowledge is light, ignorance is darkness
french: Le savoir est lumière, l'ignorance ténèbres

arabic: اللي ما عندو الفلوس كلامو مسوس
literal_translation: Who has no money, his words are rotten

cultural_note: Optimistic core belief — in the end, goodness wins.

darija: Rrjal b l2af3al mashi b lakwal
english: Men are judged by deeds, not words
french: Les hommes se jugent par leurs actes
pronunciation: r-RJAL b l-2AF-3AL ma-SHI b l-AK-wal

french: La pauvreté n'est pas une honte
On ne peut échapper au destin
cultural_note: Deep fatalism in Moroccan culture — maktub (it is written).
literal_translation: What is written cannot be avoided

french: J'ai un gros mal de tête

cultural_note: Very common for travelers. Ask for Smecta or Imodium — available without prescription.

french: Donnez-moi qqch pour le mal de tête

cultural_note: Important boundary phrase, especially in crowded souks.

english: No, thanks. I don't want it.
french: Non, merci. Je n'en veux pas.
cultural_note: Firm but polite refusal. Works for persistent sellers, guides, taxi drivers.

english: I want to speak to the manager
